prose.p:
Required Hardware (One of...):
i386 : "old" IBM PC, or "new" IBM PC with old compiler
i686 : "new" IBM PC with recent compiler
ppc : "new" Macintosh (IS NOT SUPPORTED YET - HELP US)
armv4l : Corel Netwinder (but jMax does not run on this)
mips : Silicon Graphics, non-PC (only tested without jMax)

Required Software:
GNU C Compiler (gcc)
GNU Make (gmake)
GNU Bash
X11 Window System (Xserver and Xlib)

Very Recommended:
jMax 2.5
jMax 3.0 support coming soon
jMax 2.4 support removed

Optional:
Greg Ward's libmpeg ("Berkeley/MNI")
a digitizer card with a Video4linux 1.x driver (videodev.h)
Ruby 1.6 with package "xmlparser" (for editing documentation)
NOTE: for help on installing and compiling jMax, please see Christian Klippel's extensive help file at as well as the jMax docs.

Also Useful:
Pentium-compatible CPU (for profiling)
CVS (for live update)
Ruby (for regenerating documentation)

NOTE: There are several different incompatible libmpeg's from different authors; I found four of them, some numbered 2 and 3 as if they were version numbers (but it seems they are not). Gridflow supports the Berkeley/MNI one (Greg Ward). It would be nice to support the others as well eventually.

list.li: Download the latest version of GridFlow and download the images pack (video4jmax-images-0.2.tar.gz). The download sites are artengine.ca and hostname.2y.net. Unpack Gridflow in /usr/local/jmax/packages (or the path of your choice), which will create a directory called 'gridflow'; unpack the images pack into that directory, which will create another one called 'gridflow/images'. You may also download Greg Ward's libmpeg from there but you have to install it separately and on your own.
Find your system type (for AMD K6 and Pentium Pro and compatibles, on Linux, this is i686-linux; if you have a recent Macintosh, this is ppc-macosx or ppc-linux)
Untar the archive with tar -xvtf gridflow_current_version.tgz in your packages directory (or elsewhere). This will create the gridflow directory and place all the files within.

Run ./configure --jmax25 from the gridflow directory. note: if you didn't install GridFlow in the packages directory, then you have to do something like ./configure --jmax25 --jmax-dist-dir your-jmax-source-directory-goes-here

./configure will try to detect some optional components (libmpeg, pentium clock, etc); error messages may appear in case of a no. usually a yes will not show anything else. In the end, the files config.make, c/src/Sources and c/src/config.h will be generated.

Stay in the same directory and do:
make ARCH=your-system-type all
make ARCH=your-system-type install
but if the first one stops because of "Error" you shouldn't try the second one.
Load ~/.jmaxrc (text). Go to the when start section. Add a line that says package require gridflow. Add this line that says dataDirectory gridflow-directory/images

prose.p: Note: If there's a problem with libmpeg anywhere in the process, you can add the option --no-mpeg to the configurator.

Note: If you want more speed, you can configure with the --fast switch, which turns off many error-detection mechanisms; if you want more speed, you could configure with --no-profiler too, but if you do that, you can no longer find out which of the objects consume the most time.

section.name: Installation process (without jMax)
section.prose:
If you are not a C programmer you probably shouldn't do this.
Use the --nojmax option instead of --jmax25. Don't do the regular make all; you can only do a make standalone. (note: You can also do make standalone when installing with jMax. in any case that command creates c/lib2/libgridflow.so which can be used without jMax).
